It builds on the CPF Phase I & II, adopting a multi-dimensional poverty approach to child vulnerability which simultaneously addresses household poverty, gender disparities, disability, HIV and risk of violence, exploitation and abuse. The CPF outcomes are: - increased availability and accessibility of age/gender-appropriate, affordable, and well-coordinated Child Protection services in targeted areas (18 districts). - families and communities in targeted areas have information, knowledge and skills on violence against children and how to protect children improved evidence-based policies and legislative instruments to address violence against children implemented and reinforced by institutional capacity.

The Child Protection Fund’s goal is to realize the basic rights of the most vulnerable children in Zimbabwe through provision of critical child protection interventions within a child and HIV-sensitive social protection framework. It builds on the CPF Phase I (2011-2016), adopting a multi-dimensional approach to child vulnerability which simultaneously addresses household poverty, gender disparities, disability, HIV and risk of violence, exploitation and abuse. Taking lessons from CPF I and II, this third phase of CPF has a stronger focus on violence reduction through prevention, information management and governance structures and capacity. The third phase does not include cash transfer.Through a theory of change developed for CPF III, the programme aims to ensure that “children, families and communities access improved preventive and responsive child protection services reinforced by household and community economic resilience in targeted areas.”
An increasing body of evidence about violence against children in Zimbabwe shows that violence is widespread and cuts across age, gender, and socio-economic status. There are many interlinked causes that include: family dislocation and an absence of positive parenting due to temporary migration; a high caseload of single and double orphans which is a legacy of the HIV pandemic; a propensity for resolving disputes violently that stems from generally high levels of trauma and stress in the country; overcrowded living conditions and high dependency ratios due to poverty and jobless-ness; children witnessing sexual relations from a very young age; and widespread unhealthy adolescent relationships in which negative coping strategies such as transactional sex are common, and in which regressive gender norms mixed with substance abuse generate high levels of intimate partner violence.
This project is co-funded with the Swiss Development Cooperation (SDC) and DFID.

Våld mot flickor och pojkar är ett utbrett problem i Zimbabwe som har förvärrats ytterligare av den ekonomiska krisen samt utbredd torka. De senaste årens utmaningar har ökat hushållens sårbarhet, lett till att sociala strukturer brutits ner, samt ökat risken för att kvinnor och barn utsätts för könsrelaterat våld både inom och utanför hemmet (såsom sexuellt våld, våld i hemmet, tvångsäktenskap, barnäktenskap, psykosocialt och emotionellt våld). Barn lider även av att ökat antal blir föräldralösa då föräldrar tvingas lämna hemmet för att söka försörjning på annan ort eller annat land, vidare brister statens förmåga att tillgodose barnrättigheter på många övriga punkter. En av tre unga flickor i Zimbabwe utsätts för sexuella övergrepp innan de fyller 16 år. Statistik för antalet pojkar som utsätts för övergrepp finns inte då det anses för skamligt för att prata om eller rapportera. Zimbabwe har även bland de högsta siffrorna vad gäller barnäktenskap och könsrelaterat våld i Södra Afrika (mer information finns att hitta i Global Gender Gap Report och i Girls Not Brides Report).
UNICEF har ansökt om finansiering på 60 miljoner kronor för stöd till sitt landprogram avseende de tematiska områdena Barns Skydd och Socialt Inkluderande mellan 2018 och 2021, (det sk Child Protection Fund CPF). Sverige har goda erfarenheter av tidigare stöd till UNICEFs barnrättsarbete i Zimbabwe. Samarbetspartnern, UNICEF, är ett FN-organ och därmed en juridisk enhet som kan ingå avtal med Sida. Parterna i avtalet, Sverige, genom Sida, och UNICEF i Zimbabwe använder för ändamålet framförhandlade avtalsmallar mellan Sida och UNICEF för att ingå ett bilateralt avtal om tematisk finansiering. DFID och Swiss Development Cooperation, de övriga givare som stödjer detta program, kommer fortsätta sitt stöd. Alla tre givarna samarbetar vad gäller uppföljning och dialog-frågor runt programmet, genom möten med UNICEF och gemensamma fältresor. DFID står för ca 50% av total budget, SDC för 30% och Sverige övriga 20% (budgeten bifogas)
De föreslagna interventionerna ska säkerställa att a) ålders- och könsanpassad service för barns skydd finns tillgänglig, och att b) samhällen och familjer i de utvalda områdena har kunskap och färdigheter för att skydda sina barn. UNICEF Zimbabwe arbetar med en rad partner för att genomföra landprogrammet, inklusive internationella, nationella och lokala icke-statliga organisationer, organisationer i det civila samhället, statliga strukturer, samhällsbaserade organisationer och olika intressegrupper. Landskontoret har ansvaret för planering, genomförande, ekonomisk förvaltning (inklusive för implementerande parter), kvalitetssäkring och övervakning av landprogrammet och därmed de svenska medel. Programsamarbetsavtal (PCA) är undertecknade mellan UNICEF i Zimbabwe och de olika implementeringspartnerna och tjänsteleverantörerna enligt behov under hela genomförandet av landprogrammet. Upphandling av konsulter och inköp av olika produkter görs i enlighet med sk HACT-regler. (mer information finns i Sida’s centrala organisationsbedömning av UNICEF). UNICEF vidareförmedlar medel till en rad civilsamhällesorganisationer men ger inget direkt budget stöd till regeringen.

description.narrative:
The CPF II supported activities were delivered in a year in which the programme context changed significantly following the onset of the COVID-19 global pandemic. UNICEF CP had begun the process of OFFICIAL developing regular Programme Documents with CPF CSO partners. The programme immediately flexed and adapted interventions to Child Protection in Emergency (CPiE) in order to respond to increasing protection risks for children due to national lockdown measures introduced by Government. The COVID19 pandemic worsened an already difficult context for vulnerable segments of the population reeling from residual effects of Cyclone Idai, drought and man-made hazards. The capacity of the social workforce was overstretched affecting response to the increasing protection and welfare caseload across country. During the year, the CPF II programme supported expansion of the National Case Management System (NCMS) from 18 to 20 districts. The initial plan was to scale up the CPF to 23 districts but cut of close to 1.5M of the FCDO contribution into the CPF in August 2020 meant the additional 3 districts that UNICEF had targeted for NCMS scale-up, could not be reached. On a positive note an additional contribution of USD1M from SDC was secured earmarked for strengthening of the NCMS MIS and delivery of mental health and psychosocial support services within the NCMS, which reduced the impact of the FCDO budget cut. 34,889 children including CWD received protection and welfare services including access to justice and critical child protection in emergency (CPiE) services through National Case Management System in the 20 CPF districts. UNICEF procured and distributed PPE, sanitisers, buckets and cloth masks for CSO partners’ and Government counterparts’ social workers. In addition, 15 critical staff at the Ministry headquarters and key staff responsible for coordination of the NCMS received cash for monthly data bundles to support them to work from home during the COVID lockdown periods. The Department of Social Development (DSD) offices in CPF districts received ICT and solar power backup equipment to enable staff to continue providing essential protection services. UNICEF provided technical assistance to strengthen the country’s legal framework and institutional capacity to deliver child protection services. However, there was limited progress on the Children’s Bill which did not go past the review by the Cabinet Committee on Legislation due to queries that needed to be resolved. The outstanding HSCT payments in four districts were cleared and 17,898 beneficiary households were reached. Interventions addressing social norms and harmful practices that perpetuate violence against children were supported through activities funded under the Plan International HPD. COVID-19 shifted most of client contact to on online platforms. Childline reported that calls to its tollfree helpline service had risen in the days of the lockdown. The Covid-19 pandemic and the subsequent lockdown measures enforced by Government increased the demand for both helpline services and case follow ups as illustrated in the graph below. The chart also shows a comparison of 2019 and 2020 Childline’s helpline calls.
Data from the helpline show that 95824 calls were received during the lock-down period and 27,715 (27%) were responsive calls where an individual was able to have a conversation with the Helpline Agent. The 116 Helpline received an average of 99,845 calls per month in 2020 as compared to an average of 65,812 in 2019. There was a spike in calls coming through during the lock-down, showing a 41% increase as compared to the same period in 2019. In 2020 UNICEF through the Spotlight Initiative programme with complementary funding from its own regular resources and CPF II provided technical assistance to strengthen the country’s legal framework and institutional capability to deliver child protection and GBV through the justice and law enforcement sectors. Key results achieved under this output in 2020 include:• UNICEF advocated for the granting of amnesty to women and children deprived of liberty, as part of Government efforts to decongest prisons during COVID-19 lock-down, and this contributed to the release of 175 women and 37 boys.• UNICEF supported provincial and national public consultations for the Disability Bill and Policy ensuring that the voices of women and children with disability were considered in the drafting and finalization processes. The Disability Policy has been finalised and will be launched by the President of Zimbabwe in 2020.• UNICEF also provided technical assistance, supported legal drafting and engaged Members of Parliament on the Cybercrime Bill and the Marriages Bill. • ZRP’s forensics investigation guidance and environment were strengthened and Victim Friendly Courts were enhanced and expanded with capacity, guidelines and operational support.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
